DOCNAME: CASE OF BOYADZHIEVA AND GLORIA INTERNATIONAL LIMITED EOOD v. BULGARIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Protection of property (Article 1 para. 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Peaceful enjoyment of possessions)
JUDGES: André Potocki;Angelika Nußberger;Mārtiņš Mits;Yonko Grozev;Gabriele Kucsko-Stadlmayer
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The second applicant was registered in DATE and has its registered place of business in GPE .
CARDINAL . At the time of the events in question the first applicant was registered as a sole trader . At that time the main commercial activity of the CARDINAL applicants was trade in medicaments .

In DATE other companies which were creditors of PERSON , including PERSON , applied for the commencement of insolvency proceedings against PERSON Their request was allowed in a judgment of CARDINAL DATE of ORG ( hereinafter “ the Regional Court ” ) , which declared company PERSON insolvent , opened insolvency proceedings and appointed a trustee . It noted that PERSON had ceased its payments to PERSON and other creditors in DATE , and held that the initial date of the company ’s insolvency was therefore DATE .
CARDINAL . In DATE the trustee prepared the first list of ORG creditors , which included company E.

In DATE company E. brought proceedings against the first applicant under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , as in force at the time ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , seeking to have the payments PERSON had made to her during the so - called “ suspect period ” – the period between the initial date of insolvency as declared by ORG and the commencement of the insolvency proceedings ( the payments described in paragraph CARDINAL above ) − declared null and void and the sum received by her returned to the insolvency estate .

CARDINAL . NORP The action was allowed in a judgment of ORG of DATE . Observing that it was undisputed that ORG had paid the first applicant ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL during the “ suspect period ” , and without analysing the matter any further , it ordered her to pay back this sum to the insolvency estate , plus default interest .
CARDINAL . That judgment was upheld on DATE by ORG ( hereinafter “ the Court of Appeal ” ) .

CARDINAL . ORG judgment was enforceable and , at the request of PERSON ’s trustee , a bailiff opened enforcement proceedings against the first applicant for the sums due to the insolvency estate . CARDINAL . In the judicial proceedings against the first applicant , in a final decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG refused to accept for examination an appeal on points of law lodged by her .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE company E. brought proceedings against the second applicant under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , as in force at the time ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , seeking to have the payments PERSON had made to it during the “ suspect period ” DATE and DATE ( payments described in paragraph CARDINAL above ) declared null and void and the sum received by the applicant returned to the insolvency estate .

CARDINAL . The action was allowed in a judgment of DATE of ORG . While it acknowledged that the transactions between the second applicant and PERSON had not damaged the latter ’s interests , because PERSON had received equivalent goods in exchange for its payments to the applicant , ORG added that LAW “ did not take account ” of such considerations . It thus ordered the second applicant to pay back to the insolvency estate the sum of ORG , plus default interest .

CARDINAL . Upon appeal by the second applicant , on DATE that judgment was upheld by ORG , which stated once again that section CARDINAL ) of LAW did not require any proof that the contested payment had damaged the interests of ORG remaining creditors ; such damage , as well as the knowledge about it , were to be considered “ presumed ” .

CARDINAL . Since ORG judgment was enforceable , a bailiff opened enforcement proceedings against the second applicant for the sums owed by it to the insolvency estate . The second applicant settled that debt , which included interest and costs and expenses related to the enforcement proceedings , in DATE .
CARDINAL . In the main judicial proceedings against the second applicant , in a final decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG refused to accept for examination an appeal on points of law lodged by it .

CARDINAL . In the insolvency proceedings against PERSON , the majority of its assets were distributed among its creditors between DATE and DATE . In CARDINAL decisions delivered in DATE the trustee in bankruptcy added the ORG to the list of creditors , with claims exceeding BGN CARDINAL . As the ORG was a privileged creditor , almost all payments from the insolvency estate after that were made to it , but a substantial proportion of the debts owed to it by PERSON nonetheless remained unpaid .

CARDINAL . The applicants did not make use of the possibility afforded to them by section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) to join the insolvency proceedings as creditors of CARDINAL other companies in a similar situation – they had also been obliged to return sums to the insolvency estate on the basis of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW did join the insolvency proceedings , but received no part of the sums owed to them .
CARDINAL . The insolvency proceedings continued until DATE , when company PERSON was wound up .
